description:
Cthulhu 1968: Black Sun 28mm Miniatures and Rulebook

Black Sun is a game of ground combat that accompanies our 28mm Black Sun range of models. It is set in another dimension that is known as Black Sun, located somewhere in an alternate jungles of Cambodia in the year 1968. The rules are designed to give you an authentic feel for warfare in the Viet Nam War and could certainly be used for this purpose. However, the game also includes some fantastic events from the alternate dimension of the Black Sun. These rules include unpredictable events – sudden rushes, explosions, ambushes, and malfunctioning weapons along with more far flung environmental and strange atmospheric manifestations – that will challenge your strategy and tactics as a tabletop general. The terrain can be as elaborate or as simple as you like; but the game is best played with lots of cover (jungle, trees, jungle, rocks, downed helicopters, ancient buildings and yet more jungle). The playing area can represent anything from an ancient city to an alien jungle canopy to a Bug-infested tunnel complex! 
Each player controls a Force about the size of a small squad (6-15 models). Some Forces may involve more models than others since they consist either of less skilled troops (like NVA militia or poorly armed and trained conscripts) or weird alien Fury Bugs whose strength lies in their overwhelming numbers. As players become more experienced, they can control larger numbers of troops as well as vehicles and incorporate more advanced rules for Viet Nam era warfare. At its most basic size (squad level), a game of Black Sun should take an hour or less to play.

—description from the rulebook

The Jackaroo board game, took two years from the publisher to create and design the game, it is a game based on teasing for non-ending laughs when teasing your opponent in different ways!It is a fun group game suitable for 2-4 players, and is perfect for kids, teens and adults, as well as the whole family.

How to play: 

     Use your personal teasing techniques to win the game with your friend in your team and get all your stones to safety zone; the more you tease your opponent, the funniest the game will be, guaranteeing that you will enjoy their angry faces.
     You have to eat opponent stones, dispose their cards, block their way from reaching their goal and swap their stones far away from their zones to be able to get your stones to your safety zone as fast as possible, and then help your friend to get their stones too to win the game. 
     Players receive their cards and move their stones in turn according to card command, each team cooperate together to reach their safety zones and to prevent opponent to reach their goal. The game may take 1-2 hours depending on used TEASING techniques. 


—description from the designer

As sellers and collectors of vintage objects at a flea market, you are always looking for the best items to bring to your shop! Collect furniture and deco items from the 1950s to the 1980s, and get the best collections, possibly stealing those items from other players! Color, type of items, and years will earn you points!

In Vintage, players place item cards face down to the side of their display case (a.k.a. their hands). This stack is known as a player's hoard. A player can look at their own hoard at any time, but may not look at other players' hoards. Players start with 1-3 cards in their display case and no cards in their hoards. On your turn, your perform three actions in this order:

1. Choose one item card from your display case and save it for later by placing it face down on top of your hoard. 
2. Then, either steal one item card from another player’s display case and add it to your display, or salvage the top card from the face-up discard pile and add it face up to your display.
3. Draw two item cards from the face-down deck, place one face up in your display and the other face up on the discard pile.

To score, lay out the 17 bonus cards and award each card to the player who has hoarded the most cards in the corresponding category.

—description from the publisher

Doctor I have a toothache!
Your patients are visiting the Monster Dentist for their checkup. Use the Mouth Mirror and place matching tooth tokens in the correct order.
Prepare for an exciting pattern matching duel. Use your Mouth mirror to check for abnormalities to quickly diagnose your patient. Do it quickly and accurately—and help more monsters than the other doctor!

In more detail, all Players begin examination together. Players use their Mouth Mirror to check for abnormalities inside their monster’s maw. Observe Teeth for color, order, and cavities then place matching Tooth Tokens on Player Board. Tooth Tokens are dual sided and players must check each side to find different teeth.

The first player to complete their Player Board shouts “Diagnosis!” and puts down their Mouth Mirror. The round ends when 1 Player completes examination. The Player who completed their examination takes the Problem Card and checks it to match with their Player Board.
If Player Board matches Problem Card, Player receives Problem Card. If Player Board does not match Problem Card. The player who ends a round with 3 Problem Cards wins.

—description from the publisher

Accetti? is a strategic card game, to win you have to make compromises with your opponents and study every round, because every move could be your last one!

Eliminate all the columns of cards you have in front of you by aligning four identical symbols before your opponents by getting rid of malus cards.

—description from the publisher (translated)
 Accetti? è un gioco di carte strategico in cui per vincere bisogna scendere a compromessi con gli avversari e  studiare attentamente ogni turno, perché ogni mossa potrebbe essere l'ultima!

Elimina tutte le colonne di carte davanti a te allineando quattro simboli uguali prima degli avversari sbarazzandoti delle carte malus.

—description from the publisher

Fireteam WWII is a set of miniature skirmish rules for platoon sized battles during the Second World War.

The rules use a dynamic card based activation system along with suppression and fire rules that allow players to use real world squad and platoon tactics.

The rulebook includes all the rules needed to play, including rules for vehicles, artillery, air support and field works as well as army lists for all of the major nations.

—description from the publisher

Challenge yourself and your friends with fascinating questions about all things American!

You can have as much help as you want and guess how your friends will fare. Just remember that guessing it wrong will cost you valuable points.

—description from the publisher

Stock-Poker combines the elements of the stock market with the gambling instinct of stock speculators. To be able to determine when to buy, sell, hold, sell short, and/or buy long is what makes or breaks stock speculators. All these factors are in the game to make Stock-Poker a fun and stimulating leisure time activity.

—description from the designer

square consists of a rulebook and a set of 35 square plastic tiles contained in a rectangular plastic box. The game was manufactured in Austria.

The players start by taking a hand of ten tiles, at random. Each plastic tile has one of three edge shapes on each side: a square, triangular, or semicircle "cutout," or a straight edge with no cutout. The players take turns placing the square tiles on the table. Tiles are placed dominoes style, adjacent to another tile, with matching types of edges in contact.

The object of the game is to form rectangles out of the square tiles. The game ends as soon as one player runs out of tiles. Scoring is based on the number of rectangles a player formed, with points deducted for any pieces the player has remaining at the end of the game.

While a single set of the game supports play by up to three players, more can play by combining multiple sets of the game.

—user summary

T'aimes-tu ça? is a game that tests the bond that reigns within player duos. To score points, players must prove that they know each other well by having the same answers. The perfect game to spark laughs, discussions and surprising revelations! Standalone version which can also be added to the Connexion base game.

Képis Rouges: is a miniatures ruleset for the War of 1870.

Simple rules (DBA type) to replay battles of the Franco-Prussian War. Can be played on a small size table (60x60 cm) with a limited number (~40+) of minis.

For 15mm miniatures.

Sequence of play:


     Movement
     Defensive Fire - non active player
     Mêlées 


Active player follow the sequence then other player repeats it on his/her turn.

—user summary

Au Nom de la Loi - Western rules, is a simulation of skimish action in the Old West, for 15/25mm miniatures.

Play sequence:
1- Movements, simultaneous
2- Combat, simultaneous
3- Moral, simultaneous

Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
2cm = 1m
1 play sequence = a few seconds

Published in French, in Vae Victis magazine issue 11.
Stack a tower with 6 columns per floor. Roll the dice and get a color. Pull out the corresponding color block without crashing the tower to win.

Pour l'Empereur! miniature ruleset for the First Empire.

Miniatures: 15/20mm - 1/72

Sequence of Play
Player A phase:

     A movements - B opportunity fires and charges
     Fire: A & B
     Corps a corps
     A & B Generals status
     Tests for maneuvers elements of A and B


Player B then play phase 1 to 5

Scale:
1 player maneuvers several division or an Army Corps
1cm = 20m
1 mini = ~60 men
1 arty mini = 3-6 guns
1 turn = 30 min

Published in French, in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary

"5150: Missions - Infestation" is a miniature wargame Core Rules system for unlimited military Missions in a complete Sci Fi Universe. With Infestation you have the rules for all of the Scenario Books to follow.

Inside you'll find:
7 Use as you want scenarios. 
16 Linked Scenarios taking you on one connected Story. 
Color Card stock counters and a Battle Board to get you into the game right away. 
Over thirteen Factions and Races to choose from. 
A low book keeping Campaign system that lets you track how well your Character does. 
Squad level man to man combat rules.

Protect your world or conquer others, the choice is up to you. Command a Squad from different Races and military units; from Rebels to the Elite ISS wearing "state of the art" Battle Tactical Armor.

All books are made for the solo and cooperative gamers in mind - no Game Master required!

Also, the rules and adventures in 5150: Missions can be used with any of our other 5150 Books, especially our companion adventure series - 5150: No Limits!

—description from the publisher

5150: No Limits - Maiden Voyage is the Core Rules for unlimited adventures in a complete Sci Fi Universe. With Maiden Voyage you have the rules for all of the Scenario Books to follow.

Inside you'll find:
14 Use as you want scenarios. 
16 Linked Scenarios taking you on one connected Story. 
Includes New Hope City - a Metro where an opportunity lies behind every danger. 
Color Card stock counters and a Battle Board to get you into the game right away. 
Over six Races to choose from. 
A low book keeping Campaign system that lets you track how well your Character does. 
Rules for planet bound and space combat with a variety of weapons and ships.

Be a Smuggler, a Pirate, maybe a Mercenary or Bounty Hunter. With over 30 Professions, there's No Limits on what you can be!

All books are made for the solo and cooperative gamers in mind - no Game Master required!

Also, the rules and adventures in 5150: No Limits can be used with any of our other 5150 Books, especially our companion military series - 5150: Missions!

—description from the publisher

A quick play, family friendly card game.
Take the Impala out around the country to collect groups – Angels, Demons, Hunters, Allies, Family, and two brothers. The player with the majority of groups at the end of the road wins. The Road So Far is a casual card game for 2-4 players.

The Road So Far is a card game for 2-4 players; recommended 8 and up.  Players take turns as “driver” of the Impala “travelling” on the board to collect character cards.  Once the majority of a group is collected, “mayhem” ensues.  Play continues until the Impala can no longer move.   At that time, the player that has the majority of group markers wins the game.

—description from the publisher

Original game title - Ñ†Ð¸Ñ€Ðº (eng. - Circus).
Typical chutes ladders type board game made in Russia. 
Game is based by silent film written, produced, and directed (1928) by Charlie Chaplin - The Circus.
The first player, who cross 100 stops road - wins the game.

—user summary

¡No Pasarán! is the first module for Guerre éclair, simple miniature wargame rules to simulate combats in the first half of the 20th century, where each player handles the equivalent of a division. It uses special command cards and a standard 32 cards deck.

For minis from 1/300 to 1/72

Sequence of play:
Command phase - only beginning of game, then:

     activation of units (using the 32 cards)
     orders
     movements
     combat


Scale:
1 cm = 50m
1 mini = ~60 men
1 model = ~10 vehicles

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary

The players have to move their bird on their own five spaces long track into the nest. Movement is determined by two dice.
On the roll of 7 or more the bird may move 1 space. If two identical numbers (doubles) are rolled, the bird advances two spaces.

The first player whose bird reaches the nest wins the game.

The game continues until all birds have reached the nest.

—user summary

L'empire des mers is a simple miniature tactical naval wargame rule for the period 1740-1815

Play sequence:

     Wind - sails setup
     Command phase
     Movement phase
     Boarding preparation phase
     Firing phase
     Boarding and mêlées
     Sails selection and ammo phase


—user summary

Nach Paris is the third module for Guerre éclair for the August 1914 campaign during World War I.
Guerre éclair is a simple miniature wargame rules to simulate combats in the first half of the 20th century, where each player handles the equivalent of a division. It uses special command cards, dice and a standard 32 cards deck.

For minis from 1/300 to 1/72

Sequence of play:
Command phase - only beginning of game, then:

     activation of units (using the regular cards)
     orders
     movements
     combat


Scale:
1 cm = 50m
1 mini = ~60 men
1 model = ~10 vehicles

Published in French, in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary

Les Trois Couleurs is a miniature wargame ruleset on the Napoleonic period.

Fast and historical, it can be used for reconstitution as well as competition.

It presents:

     Universal basing system,
     Operational level,
     Tactical phase, either in a conventional alternate manner, or simultaneous.
     Orders, command structure, generals, formations and movement, fire, corps à corps and moral
     basis elements for campaign games,
     National characteristics,
     for key nations, detailed data (moral and composition) at 25 key battles
     a list of all generals (160+) who commanded a brigade or a corps
     "un état d'esprit"


—user summary

Be the first to discover all the numbers from 1 to 6 that the dwarves hide.

The goal of the game is to be the first with all your 6 cards open and without any special cards among them.

Bugs Building is a twist on Jenga that is perfect for young learners. In this simple game, players take turns rolling the die, then removing a corresponding bug from the tower and placing it on top. The goal is to remove the bugs without toppling the tower.

Felicior Augusto, Melior Traiano (Happier than Augustus, Better than Trajan) is a skirmish miniatures rules for the 1st century AD in the Roman Empire.
Designed for 25/30mm miniatures.

Sequence of play:

     Initiative
     Actions (movement, corps-a-corps, throw)
     End of turn


Scale:
1 mini = 1 man
1 cm = 1 m

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary

Volnitza !

Simple miniature wargame rules for the Russian Civil War

For minis: 15 to 60mm

Turn Sequence:

     Orders attribution
     Action Points calculation
     Orders revelation
     Movement and fire step for specific orders 
     Movement and fire step for specific orders
     Movement and fire step for specific orders
     Moral step


Scale:
Brigade or Division

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.

—user summary

It has come time to honor the traditions of the past. The members of our Great Society have gathered to perform the Sacred Rites this summer solstice, honoring our most divine symbols and idols.

Except for the part where not everyone remembers what they were.

To play Sacred Rites, players take on the mantles of Believers, each privately informed of the topic of a Rite. The catch: Some (or sometimes none) of the Believers are left out, making them Outsiders. Each Believer then submits what they recall of the Rite, such as the chants, the time of day, the food for the feast, or even the special shapes, smells, or colors. Once each Believer has helped remember the Rite, an accusation occurs: Can each Believer point out an Outsider? Can the Outsiders fake their way through it and guess the topic? In the end, only the most confident, creative, and devout among the Believers will be declared the winner and Master of Ceremonies of the Sacred Rites.

—description from the publisher

Fort is a 2-4 player card game about building forts and following friends.

In Fort, you're a kid! And like many kids, you want to grow your circle of friends, collect pizza and toys, and build the coolest fort.

By doing this cool stuff, you'll score victory points, and at the end of the game, the player with the most victory points wins! Your cards not only let you take actions on your own turn, but also let you follow the other players' actions on their turns. Will you devote yourself to your own posse, or copy what the other kids are doing?

But be careful as your carefully constructed deck might start losing cards if you don't actually use them. After all, if you don't play with your friends, why should they hang out with you anymore?

—description from the publisher

Not to be confused with Escape Room: The Game 2, this is actually the Spanish version of Escape Room: The Game (Escape Rooms II).

Both the English and Spanish editions contain Secret Agent, Space Station, and The Dentist, but the Spanish version also contains The Casino.

Will you expand your cities , double your opponent or simply take advantage of what your adversary try to develop?

In Divercité, you will have these 3 ways of playing!

The game is accessible thanks to easy rules, but to become an expert of Divercité, you will need reflexion and strategy.

In each turn you will set up resources and build cities on the most promising territories.
Each city needs his owns resources but don't forget: diversity is the key.

A fast-paced family party game of modelling charades where players pick a card and model a sculpture in Plasticine that their teammates need to recognise and guess correctly within the given time limit.

In today’s feverish turmoil of new currencies, corporate magnates force usually layabout hogs to work tirelessly on cryptofields, digging for different kinds of oinkoins until they are blue in their snouts. But true Swintus can overcome any hardships. All you need is simply to squander away the whole capital entrusted to you and be the first to leave on vacation. Your glorious business venture will become a legend among all lazybones of neighboring (crypto)farms.

To win the game you must be the first player to get rid of all of your cards. Winner scores an amount of points equal to number of all cards in their opponents’ hands at the end of the game. We recommend to play a series of games, up to a certain number of points, depending on the number of players. First player to get certain amount of points will be the winner of the series.
Turn the number of discs taken in the die and try to form words with them. In this game, you win whoever wrote the most words with the discs.

In this amazing game of speed and logic you have one goal: to put the people of your team in the marked places. But beware, it's not easy to remember who's what.

You all become objects of the house. So, before calling the next occupant of the vacant seat, think about it. If you choose the wrong person your team will be harmed!

Can you think a few rounds ahead and win the match?

In each Q case, you try to solve a mystery case with 32 clues, with players revealing one clue at a time until all cards have been revealed or discarded. During your turn, each player must perform one of the following actions:

A) Reveal information:
Choose a card from your hand and place it on the table, so all players can read or see the entire information.
We recomend you read out loud all shared info when you place it on the table. If you play a clue that happens to be irrelevant
to the case, you lose points at the end of the game, but be careful! Some clues are vital to resolve the case.

You can share and expose your theories at any moment and talk about the cards you have in your hand but you cannot show them to the other players and you may only read out loud the words written in bold or the text framed inside an image:

At the end of the game, when all clue cards have been revealed or discarded, you must check carefully all the available information and prepare a theory of what happened, working all together. Then, open the questionnaire and answer all questions. During this phase of the game, you can speak freely about your discarded cards, or the information you remember of them. Each right answer will add two points.

—user summary

Adam Lockwood ha desaparecido en su trabajo. ¿Qué ha pasado?, ¿por qué? Sigue las pistas con tu equipo de investigadores para responder éstas y otras preguntas. ¿Resolveréis el misterio del trabajador desaparecido?
—description from the back of the box

Full Captain is a Tactical Naval Wargame, designed to play actions between small groups of ships or individual ships. The game is specially designed for our 10mm Naval Range, which scale allows gamers to manoeuvre ships and fight actions using miniatures representing guns and crew members.

The Rules cover the entire “Golden Era” of sailing ships, from the mid XVII century to the first quarter of the XIX century.

Full Captain allows players to recreate the bloody boardings of the famous pirate “Black Beard”, the coastal actions of Privateers and smugglers against the Revenue authorities (His Majesty’s Customs & Revenue, Royal Navy, US Coast Guard and Revenue, French Gendarmerie, Spanish Navy, etc.), as well as small engagements between, single ships, ranging from Gunboats to big 74-gun ships of the line.

—description from the publisher

In this art gallery someone had a lot of fun messing with the monsters portraits. Maybe your opponent?
You must quickly try to recreate the portraits so that they will appear like the original ones.

You won't be using paint and brush to do it; instead you'll be handling coloured rolling marbles trying to place them in to the right place in the right order.

Place your frame, get the marbles ready and go! The fastest painter wins!

Test your knowledge and cunning by playing Cunning Concoction Bluff Trivia by Clarendon Games! If you don’t know the answer to a trivia question, bluff without being caught out and still win the card. Includes 80 trivia cards to test your cunning and knowledge.

Fun games to cure boredom!
Great for stocking stuffers and impulse
Small travel sized card games
Mixes humour and trivia

—description from the publisher

On January 1st 2019 the two Belgian cities Deinze and Nevele were fused into ¨Deinze in het land van Nevele". To celebrate this, AD Delhaize Deinze worked together with Hasbro to create this new version of Monopoly with locations from both cities.

Not to be confused with other games with similar names. Neither the publisher nor the designer is indicated, but the game comes in an envelope saying "Enclosed: Your Free Animal Triva Game", so one might imagine that it was a promotional item or was given away for free with some product or service.
There are 30 cardboard rectangles with numbers from 1 to 30, and another 30 cardboard rectangles in 6 different groups (indicated by pictures and words): birds, insects, primates, fish, mammals, and reptiles (however, the reptile rectangles have a picture of a frog on them). One of each of these 6 groups has a stars, in addition to the pictures and the names of the groups.
The two different types of squares (numbers and animals) are put into two different containers. Players (presumably without looking) take one rectangle from each container, and this determines which question (from the question sheet) they have to answer. For example, if a player drew 6 and primates, he would have to answer the question "True or False: Lemurs and lorises have huge eyes so they can see well at night". (The correct answer here is "true"). Most correct answers give the player 5 points, but if a starred rectangle was drawn,  a correct answer gives 10 points.
The game can last a chosen period of time (in which case whoever has amassed the highest total wins) or until a set target of points is reached (in which case whoever has reached that target wins).

The aim of the game is to sail on the river and try to discover the most valuable unknown creatures (discovery cards). You can buy new tools from the cargo ship to make your search more successful and to have the most sensational publication at the end of the game.

At the beginning of each round players choose from their movement tokens the one which has a number showing how far they want to move. You cannot reuse it until you run out of the other movement tokens. You can move your ship forward or backwards on the river as far as the selected movement token shows.

If your ship lands on a tile with a buoy, take a look at the card at the top of the discovery deck. If the card shows a tool that you own, you are lucky! Keep the card. On the other side of the card, you can see your new discovery and the number of victory points/score. The player with the highest number of victory points at the end wins the game.

Narrow Seas is a fast playing set of coastal forces naval rules designed for use with models from 1/300 to 1/1200. Book keeping is minimal, with speed and damage recorded for each vessel on a card through a series of Levels rather than keeping track of damage points and exact speeds.
As well as rules for gunnery, torpedo and depth charge attacks there are optional and additional rules covering anti submarine warfare, boarding actions and battles involving forces on land.

Data for over 200 classes and individual ships and over 70 aircraft types covering the navies of Great Britain, Germany, the United States, Japan, France, Italy, the Soviet Union, the Netherlands, Finland, Bulgaria, Romania and Tito’s Partisan navy are included.

—description from the publisher

Common Threads is the family card game that lets you play four different games with the same deck! Featuring cool characters and colorful graphics, each card in the deck matches in one way. It's up to you to spot the matching elements, play your cards quickly and outsmart your opponents. Cards feature quirky characters -- like a unicorn, robot, dinosaur and more -- dressed in colorful outfits and accessories. Do two different cards show the same character? That's a match. Are two different characters wearing the same color shirt? That's a match. Are two different characters each holding a skateboard? That's a match! But act quickly, because each game is based on how fast you can spot the matching elements. This fast-paced family card game is lots of fun for 7 year olds and up.

-from the publisher's website

Do you want to be the RICHEST player?

Play cards and try to be the first player to build your BANK to the highest value of $10 million. Play a STEAL card to try and grab the card you need from another player or hang on to a card you know another player needs. While doing all that try not to go BANKRUPT before another player finishes their BANK and wins the game! Win the game and you can say, "It's all pure profit!"

-description from designer

Four millennia ago on the eastern bank of the Nile river was laid the foundation of the Temple of Amun-Ra. Over the course of two thousand years, the temple complex was gradually expanded and became widely known as "The Most Select of Places" (Ipet-Isut), boasting the largest religious building in the world. Today, the site is known as Karnak, located at Luxor in modern-day Egypt.

Join ancient Pharaohs in creating and growing one of the most impressive sites the world has seen, honoring the Egyptian gods Horus, Ra, Hathor, Bastet, Thoth, and Osiris. You must carefully manage the balance of your actions, preparing for the reckoning by the goddess Maat.

The game board in Tekhenu: Obelisk of the Sun is divided into six sections, each associated with an Egyptian god: Horus, Ra, Hathor, Bastet, Thoth, and Osiris. In the center stands an impressive obelisk (Tekhenu) that casts its shadow onto different parts of the board. As a result, the area around the obelisk is divided into sunny, shaded, and dark sections, depending on how the obelisk casts its shadow at that particular moment. As the game progresses, the sun's rotation alters which sections are sunny, shaded, or dark.

The game takes place over multiple rounds. Each round, players draft dice and perform actions associated with the value of the die and the section from which the die was drafted. Dice come in five colors, and each die is considered Pure, Tainted, or Forbidden depending on the color of the die and the position of the obelisk's shadow. While you may never draft Forbidden dice, you are free to draft any other die, whether Pure or Tainted.

As you draft the dice, you must consider not only the general availability of dice — if no dice are available in a given section, then you cannot readily perform the action associated with that section — but also which value die to draft. You must also consider the purity of the dice to draft, as you must balance your Pure and Tainted actions if you want to have a more favorable position in turn order.

When you draft a die, you can perform an action depending on the section you took the die from. Each of the actions corresponds to a different Egyptian god: Horus, Ra, Hathor, Bastet, Thoth and Osiris. Instead of a god action, you can choose to produce, generating resources based on the color and value of the die, but beware of producing in excess of your production capacity, as this is Greed and adds Taint to your balance!

Two scoring phases occur during the game, during which players earn victory points based on the workshops, quarries, buildings, statues and pillars they have built, as well as the happiness of their people and production capacity of their resources. However, players must also keep a healthy amount of resources around to sustain their population or they suffer negative consequences.

Project made possible by the great and beautiful collection of Gianpaolo Bistulfi, who in many years of modelling career has personally painted thousands of toy soldiers. Now these soldiers will be at your disposal to obtain, with little effort, entire armies of battalions of infantry, squadrons of cavalry, batteries of cannons, houses and buildings, trees and much more material needed to create the scenes of your battle. We also explain tricks and modes for a good assembly of the pieces, as well as the official rules for playing wargame. All in 50 pages full of hundreds of soldiers supplied in the standard scale of 25/28mm that you can, for personal use only, photocopy on thicker cardboard and thus get armed with the desired size. So what are you waiting for? Wear the general commander’s shoulder pads, equip yourself with a capable table, a practical ruler to measure, a pair of dice and get ready to lead hundreds or thousands of armed in epic and exciting battles of history!

—description from the publisher

With Su Ho Vuong, you will own the Tiger with the ability to summon and accompany the legendary characters including demons, gods, heroes, kings, queens, princesses, craft ancestors. , ... will fight together with another force to protect the country - the land of "Con Rong Chau Tien" (the Dragon's son and the Fairy's nephew).

Su Ho Vuong is the first trading card game in Vietnam. Each person builds for himself a set of 30 cards.

Currently, there are over 200 different cards, including 100 Guardian Gods, 60 Treasures and 40 Tactical cards.

The game has 2 game modes:

     Team boss fights: from 1 to 6 people
     Countervailing: divided into 2 teams fighting each other, playing 2 or 4 or 6 people.


—description from the publisher

You can write it anyway ... in the end it has to mean the same thing.

Answer questions to which there is no good answer and collect more points by matching your answers with those of other players.

How we play PHOQUE!

Draw a card and read it aloud.

Everyone writes their answer.

We compare answer and every one that looks the same gets points.

If you're really hot, you might get bonus points!

Here is in very summary how the 5 types of card are played:

There is not really a good answer. Each player scores one (1) point for each answer identical.

A question related to the reader. Each player scores one (1) point per answer identical to another player and two (2) additional points if you have the same answer as the reader.

A question related to one of the players. Each player scores one (1) point for each answer identical to another player.

A question where you have to find the common point between two things, people, objects, etc. Each player scores one (1) point for each answer identical to another player and two (2) additional points if you have found the answer on the card.



Vous aurez beau l’écrire de toutes les façons... à la fin du compte faut que ça dise la même affaire.Répondez à des questions auxquelles il n’y a pas vraiment de bonne réponse et ramassez plus de points en matchant vos réponses avec celles des autres joueurs.

Comment on joue à PHOQUE!

Pige une carte et lis-la à voix haute.

Tout le monde écrit sa réponse..

On compare les réponses des joueurs et tous ceux qui en ont une pareille font des points.

Si t’es vraiment hot, t’auras peut-être des points boni!

Voici en très résumé comment se jouent les 5 types de carte :

Il n’y a pas vraiment de bonne réponse. Chaque joueur marque un (1) point par réponse identique à un autre joue.

Les questions qui ont un lien avec le lecteur. Chaque joueur marque un (1) point par réponse identique à un autre joueur et deux (2) points supplémentaires si vous avez la même réponse que le lecteur.

Les questions qui ont un lien avec l’un des joueurs. Chaque joueur marque un (1) point par réponse identique à un autre joueur.

Les questions où devez trouver le point commun entre deux choses, personnes, objets, etc. Chaque joueur marque un (1) point par réponse identique à un autre joueur et deux (2) points supplémentaires si vous avez trouvé la réponse de la carte.
